reviewText:
In a nutshell it's Ghosts 'n Goblins mixed with Mega Man. The price point is well chosen, so if you like 8/16 bit platform games you should really consider to give this one a try.

The game isn't easy, but it is fair and the levels aren't very innovative, but still well designed. The gameplay reminded me a lot of Ghosts 'n Goblins and I think that is intended. It's really more of a homage and not a ripoff and there are a lot of new features included to keep it interesting. First and foremost the inclusion of different armor types that grant you different abilities. While this isn't new at all, it certainly feels right when you mix it with a Ghosts 'n Goblins game.

The graphics are colourful and well made. At times they might feel a bit random, but overall they are fitting to the style of the levels. The music and sounds are good and also add to the atmosphere of the game.

I'd like to leave a few words about the developer of the game as I think it does matter in this case. There was a problem with the game on launch day and the developer put a lot of effort into fixing it and releasing a patch just a few hours after the launch on Steam which fixed the problem. Afterwards I posted about a gameplay problem that I had and again the developer looked into it right away and offered a fix within a day. That plus the price of the game really show that there are indie developers out there that love making games and care for their customers. My sincere respect for that.

If you like retro games and/or challenging games you should really give this game a try.

reviewText:
Yeah, this is definitely one of those games that went un-noticed until recently. It's like Ghouls 'n Ghosts, and it's absolutely amazing! The soundtrack is really good, especially in the later levels. To fully appreciate the game, play it on Normal first, then go to Hard, then if you're brave enough, Retro.

Like Ghouls 'n Ghosts, there are favorable weapons, then there are weapons you'd consider absolute trash. In the case of Cast of the Seven Godsends, the best weapon(s) have better hitboxes as well as higher damage. When I was routing a speedrun I came across this very useful information that just might help you out: No matter what weapon you have, a god power will make it infinitely better. The Mace's arc is so bad, but with the Wind Armor's help it has a nicer angle that can help defeat those shielded enemies.

All this to say, Caste of the Seven Godsend is incredibly diverse. There are so many different potential playstyles, whether you favor certain god armors over others, or certain weapons over others. It very much rewards the player can mash attack the quickest, so keep that in mind. Either way, the game's fantastic, and it's got soooo much spirit.

This game is almost literally Ghosts 'n Goblins/Ghouls 'n Ghosts, down to the intro.

While the art is nice, something feels wrong with it, like they added too much to make it look good, but it ends up being too busy, making everything blend together and may give you some problems playing. And for some reason whatshisface keeps rollerskating in the map screen.

The commands are responsive, but the character moviment and animation feels slow and heavy, maybe the devs are trying to emulate Arthur's moviment or maybe I'm too used to playing the actual Ghosts 'n Goblins, because whatshisface jumps are not high enough for most platforms. It doesnt helps that I get random slowdowns when there is
a light source on the screen.

The game only uses 2 buttons besides moviment, attack and jump, and for some reason the jump button is set as the cancel/quit button, making me quit the game twice before actually finding out what I was doing.

You use literally every weapon from Ghosts 'n Goblins, they only differ in appareance, and probably for fidelity, they kept that one weapon which the throw arc makes it fly just above the enemies, screwing over your aim.

You also can find magic armors just like on Ghosts 'n Goblins, although there are at least 6 of them. Instead of having one armor that boosts your current weapon, each armor comes with a preset weapon, so you have to know which armor has before equiping it.
Getting the armors is also a bit weird, you break the orb (like the chest in GnG), a beach ball comes out of it, you hold your attack button until symbols start to flash above you and let it go once the icon you want is showing up.

Enemies are a pain, the first level has TWO different enemies that are immune to frontal damage, one can only be hit while he is attacking (throwing a brick with infinite horizontal range) and the other only by hitting his back, but getting too close makes him turn around and hitting him only once also makes him turn around, and he only turns back if you get really far from him.

Bosses are another pain, the first one took me several tries because 90% of the time he would teleport to outside my range and the second one was almost impossible since I had the previously said arc weapon, his fireball attack had a ridiculously fast tell and it made a firefield where it hits, so you have to pull a tricky backwards jump, face him, shoot away and hope the weapon arc hits his head (the only place he takes damage, of course). Then he would jump to outside my view and spam fireballs from there, where I had no time to react because I couldnt see the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ fireballs.

In short, it tries to be a Ghosts 'n Goblins, but it doesnt plays as such. Not a bad game, but just makes you want to play Ghosts 'n Goblins. Maybe if you never played one, you will do far better than I did in this game.

Honestly, At first glance, I thought that this game was some kind of low quality Ghost 'n Goblins clone that tried to cash in on nostalgia, but I was wrong.

Why is this game fun? Because of its simple  Get rewarded if you don't fail loop. It also manage to keeps itself fresh until the end with varying enemies and challenges. Each levels has its own theme and brings in something new.

As soon as you start the game you'll feel at home with the premise and you'll be sent directly into the fray.

The armor/life system is pretty straight forward and addicting; If you get damaged while wearing an armor you lose it. If you get damaged while not wearing any armor you die. If you manage to find an armor pick-up without losing your armor it'll turn into an elemental suit.

Multiple Weapons (Dagger/Sword/Maul/Hammer/Chakram)
Each weapons work very differently (Range/Damage/Speed/Behavior)

Multiple Suits (Earth, Ice, Fire, Lightning, Plague, Wind & a Secret Armor)
Each suits of armor have their own strength/weakness. The whole system makes you feel like you're playing completely different characters.

You know what the best thing is?Every weapon/armor combination comes with its own attack and special ability]. Summon a massive eagle to wipe your foes, Spawn a giant mushroom under the boss, clone yourself or maybe you'd just like to fly around.

TLDR This game is an awesome platformer that pays homage to the Ghosts 'n Goblins franchise with its own twist. I had a blast. 5/5

reviewText:
Ok, I promised a review- although I haven't played the game through yet.

First off I want to mention this- the developers are one of the nicest I have had the pleasure of talking with.  If you research a little history about their project, it has been several long years and a lot of work for a small group of people to put together.  They are also kind and willing to listen to feedback from the community.  I can say from personal experience in talking to many other developers- this is a rare and treasured quality that you cannot learn to be but simply - ARE.

Now, as one more aside, I have bought copies of this game for several people and one of them is a developer of AAA titles who found the game to be way too hard haha-  but also a quality product with few issues.  He used to love Ghosts and Goblins and this was of course a great throwback.

About the game:
- This game is a niche title.  You must fill several pre-requisites to enjoy this game.  You must have time, patience and a high tolerance for repeating levels in almost its entirety.  You must also be a fan of the Ghost and Goblins series and their spin-offs.  The game adheres to many of the limitations of the characters before him- no throwing weapons at an angle but only up.  You also cannot double jump or drop down a platform.
- You DO have a health bar of a sort that you build up through picking up protection(s) when you have a special armor.  Armor are easy to come by and once you learn their locations you can power up quite a bit to withstand monumental colossal screw-ups.

I can understand some people's complaints about the game:

- the difficulty: yes even on normal it is punishing.  But this is the style of the title.  It is supposed to be so.  However, in today's gaming market overflowing with companies who want to strike it rich in the new virtual gold rush, it is more of a negative than a positive.  I love the challenge personally, but I have come to realize that because many gamers are now older, esp. the retro crowd, they do not have the time available to dedicate to learning tough and complicated intricacies of any one particular game.  Jumping in and jumping out with a mild or moderate challenge is enough for most people.  The challenge needs to be tuned to this crowd first, with the choice available for the purist hard core challenge seeker.

Also following Ghosts and Goblins tradition, you cannot avoid sometimes picking up some of the WORST weapons for a situation at some of the WORST times.  And you may end up stuck with it for a long time in the duration of your run through- Just like GnG.


- There are a lot of positives though.  The sound track is great.  I love video game music and the sound effects resound sharply throughout and the music captures the mood perfectly.  The weapons can be amazing- like the sword.  I have flown through many a level without any truoble because of default armor and a sword in hand.  It is just amazing.  Once you start holding onto your magic armor abilities of the seven classes of gods you can choose from, you will have fun discovering all the variations in their powers.  There are a lot of imaginative ideas balanaced with fair charge shots versus the power of each transformed bullet you throw.  The game has some interesting art- I love the style and it feels like I am running through a rotating painted scene inside an intricate fantasy story book.  The bosses are strict- meaning that you must adhere to their patterns that you have very little time to learn the first go around.  Again, you will die quickly even if you have a lot of hits to spare.

Lastly, the demon armor is hilariously OP.  Once you start not taking unecessary hits, you will earn this armor through multiple drops and then destroy the game in many places.  The game will reward tenacity and perfection with what will end up seeming like a breeze with OP gear.  But what you wont realize is, that getting there, you earned it with a lot of hard work.

*One important detail!!!
- There is an update coming eventually that will address a lot of concerns, new animations as well as some gameplay changes and item pickups.  I do not know about a save option yet, but this would be great.  I personally hope they allow for a level select feature!!!

I recommend this game because I respect the developers, their passion for this title and it is a fun and challenging tribute to GnG.  Good luck.  If you ask, I may even buy you a copy :D

reviewText:
Fifteen minutes was all I could take of Cast of the Seven Godsends. Rarely have I been so immediately and thoroughly repulsed by a game. I can't even bear the thought of loading it up again, and so I sit here struggling to describe my loathing based on mere minutes of play. But I assure you, it won't be as much of a struggle as playing the thing was.

Cast of the Seven Godsends opens with your baby being stolen by some demon thing and stuck on some pulsating altar, and then you die maybe, except seven mutant people combine Captain Planet style to bring you back? It's not really important, despite your character having dialogues with all the bosses and at the end of every stage. You're trying to get to the end of each level, avoiding or murdering the bizarre cast of monsters that stand in your way. Your basic attack is throwing daggers, but pickups can change them to hammers, shuriken, maces, and so on. Collecting other powerups gives you familiars or lets you transform into one of the seven godsends, each with its own special attacks.

It's not a bad premise, but the presentation murders its potential in gruesome fashion. I don't even know where to start... everything about CotSG feels wrong. The graphics are strangely blurry (the only resolution options are 720p and 1080p), badly proportioned, densely packed, and clash everywhere. The city level in particular is a chromatic fever dream of pastel backgrounds, bold enemies, fog effects, and washed-out platforms. The enemies are stiffly animated and glide back and forth like a GameMaker demo reel. Hits lack impact, sounds are missing, contact with platforms is iffy at best, and so on. Honestly the game feels more like a ROM hack than a retail product.

By the end of my fifteen minutes I was starting to feel physically ill. I'm not making this up, some games just look and feel so wrong to me that I start to feel legitimately gross playing them. Even if you're not as sensitive as me, there's no reason to bother with this mess because levels get frustrating fast out of poor level and encounter design. The nicest thing I can say about it is that it feels a bit like one of those lost NES or Genesis games that no one heard of. But then I immediately regret bringing it to anyone's attention lest they attempt to play it, so maybe we're all better off forgetting about this one.

Anybody can't do a ghouls and ghosts clone... And this game is the living proof of it !

While animations are pretty nice (and I like the death of some enemies) just like the graphics (it's RPG maker graphic style, if you like that kind of stuff, especially the hero is a clone of some RPG maker character), while the powers (infinite until you get hit too many time) are superb and changing following your weapon and so are the attack animations... I can't give this game a thumbs up and I would discourrage anyone hoping to find a reasonable ghouls and ghost clone to buy it !

So why don't I advise this game? Let me say that hit box are not well defined and so are the platforms on which you seem to jump on or not randomly + the graphics make it sometimes hard to define what is a platform what is not which makes it really frustrating.

The game play of the character doesn't feel good, you can upgrade his jump and speed ability with some powerups you find here and there but it still make the character lousy to move around and jump.

A ghost 'n goblin imitation, which feels like it needs to be tweaked differently to be enjoyable.

The Main issue I have with this game is not having the ability to save your progression, which makes it impossible to complete unless you have the amount of time or enthusiastic to finish through the end in one sitting. Also its a real shame to never be fully equip or experience the godly transformation power ups long enough through the adventure because its utlize these items as a health bar.

I see a potential in what this game could of been but others might see it differently.
I can't recommend or see myself playing any further until they add a save progression, which would allow me to judge it more fairly.
